arguments.argument: Making birth control OTC increases accessibility for everyone.
It empowers people to manage their reproductive health independently.
Over-the-counter options reduce healthcare costs and barriers.
It’s safe—birth control has been used for decades with few side effects.
Removing the prescription requirement helps those without insurance.
It reduces unintended pregnancies and related healthcare burdens.
Women in rural or underserved areas gain easier access.
It aligns with how other countries safely distribute birth control.
Pharmacists can still guide consumers on usage and side effects.
Convenience boosts consistency and adherence.
OTC birth control may lead to misuse without medical guidance.
It could discourage regular doctor visits and screenings.
Not all contraceptives are suitable for every person without evaluation.
Insurance might stop covering birth control if it's sold OTC.
It may be less effective if used improperly without consultation.
Teens may access it without parental knowledge or education.
It removes an opportunity for doctors to discuss long-term options.
Potential side effects and risks might go unnoticed without supervision.
It may normalize birth control use without addressing root issues.
Lack of regulation in some states may lead to inconsistent access anyway.
